problems.title: Problem 1
problems.content: The current in a 50 μH inductor is known to be i<sub>L</sub> = 18te<sup>-10t</sup> A for t≥0, where t is in seconds. Assume the passive sign convention.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Choose the correct expression for the voltage across the inductor for  t>0.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find the power (in microwatts) at the terminals of the inductor when
parts.need: Express your answer in microwatts to three significant figures.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Is the inductor absorbing or delivering power at t = ms?

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Find the energy (in microjoules) stored in the inductor at
parts.need: Express your answer in microjoules to three significant figures.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Find the time (in milliseconds) when maximum energy is stored in the inductor.
parts.need: Express your answer in milliseconds to three significant figures.

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: Find the maximum energy (in microjoules) stored in the inductor.
parts.need: Express your answer in microjoules to three significant figures.

problems.title: Problem 2
problems.content: The triangular current pulse shown in (Figure 1) is applied to a 20 mH inductor. Use the passive sign convention.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Write the expression that describes i(t)in the interval t<0. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in amperes in terms of t.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Write the expression that describes i(t) in the interval 0≤t≤5ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in amperes in terms of t.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Is the inductor absorbing or delivering power at t = ms?
parts.need: Express your answer in amperes in terms of t.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Find the energy (in microjoules) stored in the inductor at
parts.need: Express your answer in amperes in terms of t.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor voltage in the interval t<0 . Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in volts in terms of t .

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor voltage in the interval 0≤t≤5ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in volts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part G
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor voltage in the interval 5ms≤t≤10ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in volts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part H
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor voltage in the interval t>10ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in volts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part I
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor power in the interval t<0. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in watts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part J
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor power in the interval 0≤t≤5ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in watts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part K
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor power in the interval 5ms≤t≤10ms. Suppose that t is in seconds
parts.need: Express your answer in watts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part L
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor power in the interval t>10ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in watts in terms of t.

parts.title: Part M
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor energy in the interval t<0. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in joules in terms of t.

parts.title: Part N
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor energy in the interval 0≤t≤5 ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in joules in terms of t.

parts.title: Part O
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor energy in the interval 5ms≤t≤10ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in joules in terms of t.

parts.title: Part P
parts.content: Derive the expression for the inductor energy in the interval t>10ms. Suppose that t is in seconds.
parts.need: Express your answer in joules in terms of t.

problems.title: Problem 3
problems.content:
The current in a 20 mH inductor is known to be
i = 40mA, t≤0;
i = A1e-10,000t + A2e-40,000t A, t≥0,
where t is in seconds. The voltage across the inductor (passive sign convention) is 28 V at t=0.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Choose the correct expression for the voltage across the inductor for t>0.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find the time, greater than zero, when the power at the terminals of the inductor is zero.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 4
problems.content:
The current in a 200 mH inductor is
i=75 mA, t≤0;
i=(B1 cos 200t + B2 sin 200t) e-50t A, ≥0,
where t is in seconds. The voltage across the inductor (passive sign convention) is 4.25 V at t = 0.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Calculate the power at the terminals of the inductor at
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: State whether the inductor is absorbing or delivering power.

problems.title: Problem 5
problems.content: The current in a <input id='p5-L' type='number'/> mH inductor is known to be -10 A for t≤0 and (-10 cos 400t - 5 sin 400t) e<sup>-200t</sup> A for t≥0 . Assume the passive sign convention.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: At what instant of time is the voltage across the inductor maximum?
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: What is the maximum voltage?
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 6
problems.content: The voltage across a 5 μF capacitor is known to be v<sub>c</sub> = 500te<sub-2500t</sub> V for t≥0, where t is in seconds.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Find the current through the capacitor for t>0. Assume the passive sign convention.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find the power at the terminals of the capacitor when
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: he capacitor absorbing or delivering power at t = μs?

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Find the energy stored in the capacitor at
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Find the maximum energy stored in the capacitor.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: Find the time when the maximum energy stored in the capacitor occurs.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 7
problems.content: The initial voltage on the 0.5 μF capacitor shown in the figure (Figure 1) is -20V. The capacitor current has the waveform shown in the figure (Figure 2).

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: How much energy is stored in the capacitor at
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: How much energy is stored in the capacitor at t = ∞ ?
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 8
problems.content: Assume that the initial energy stored in the inductors of both figures is zero. Suppose that

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Find the equivalent inductance of (Figure 1) with respect to the terminals a, b.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find the equivalent inductance of (Figure 2) with respect to the terminals a, b.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 9
problems.content: The three inductors in the circuit in the following figure are connected across the terminals of a black box at t=0. The resulting voltage for t>0 is known to be v<sub>0</sub> = 2000e<sup>-100t</sup> V.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: If i<sub>1</sub> (0) = -6A and i<sub>2</sub> (0) = 1A, find i<sub>o</sub> (0).
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find i<sub>o</sub> (t), t≥0.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Find i<sub>1</sub> (t), t≥0.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Find i<sub>2</sub> (t), t≥0.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Find the initial energy stored in the three inductors.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: Find the total energy delivered to the black box.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part G
parts.content: Find the energy trapped in the ideal inductors.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 10
problems.content: The three inductors in the circuit in the following figure are connected across the terminals of a black box at t=0. The resulting voltage for t>0 is known to be v<sub>0</sub> = 2000e<sup>-100t</sup> V.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: If i<sub>1</sub> (0) = -6A and i<sub>2</sub> (0) = 1A, find i<sub>o</sub> (0).
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find i<sub>o</sub> (t), t≥0.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Find i<sub>1</sub> (t), t≥0.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Find i<sub>2</sub> (t), t≥0.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Find the initial energy stored in the three inductors.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: Find the total energy delivered to the black box.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part G
parts.content: Find the energy trapped in the ideal inductors.
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 11
problems.content: The three inductors in the circuit in the figure are connected across the terminals of a black box at t=0. (Figure 1) The resulting voltage for t>0 is known to be v<sub>o</sub>=2000e<sup>-100t</sup> V.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: If i<sub>1</sub>(0) = -6A and i<sub>2</sub> (0) = 1A, how many milliseconds after the switch is opened is the energy delivered to the black box 80% of the total energy delivered?
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Find the equivalent capacitance with respect to the terminals a, b for the circuit shown in (Figure 1). Suppose that
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Determine the the initial voltage drop for the equivalent capacitance with respect to the terminals a, b for the circuit shown in (Figure 1).
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Find the equivalent capacitance with respect to the terminals a, b for the circuit shown in (Figure 2). Suppose that
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Determine the the initial voltage drop for the equivalent capacitance with respect to the terminals a, b for the circuit shown in (Figure 2).
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 13
problems.content: The two series-connected capacitors in (Figure 1) are connected to the terminals of a black box at t = 0. The resulting current i (t) for t>0 is known to be 20e<sup>-t</sup> μA .

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Replace the original capacitors with an equivalent capacitor and select the correct expression for v<sub>o</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Select the correct expression for v<sub>1</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Select the correct expression for v<sub>2</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: How much energy is delivered to the black box in the time interval 0≤t<∞ ?
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: How much energy was initially stored in the series capacitors?
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: How much energy is trapped in the ideal capacitors?
parts.need: Express your answer to three significant figures and include the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 14
problems.content: The four capacitors in the circuit in the following figure are connected across the terminals of a black box at t=0. The resulting current i<sub>b</sub> for t>0 is known to be i<sub>b</sub> = -5e<sup>-50t</sup> mA, If v<sub>a</sub> (0) = -20V, v<sub>c</sub> (0) = -30V, and v<sub>d</sub> (0) = 250V. (Figure 1)

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: Find v<sub>b</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Find v<sub>a</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Find v<sub>c</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Find v<sub>d</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Find i<sub>1</sub> (t) for t≥0.

parts.title: Part F
parts.content: Find i<sub>2</sub> (t) for t≥0.

problems.title: Problem 15
problems.content: The four capacitors in the circuit in the figure are connected across the terminals of a black box at t=0. (Figure 1) The resulting current for t>0 is known to be i<sub>b</sub> = -5e<sup>-50t</sup> mA.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: If v<sub>a</sub> (0) = -20 V, v<sub>c</sub> (0) = -30 V, and v<sub>d</sub> (0) = 250 V, calculate the initial energy stored in the capacitors.
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part B
parts.content: Calculate the final energy stored in the capacitors.
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part C
parts.content: Calculate the total energy delivered to the black box.
parts.need: Express your answer to five significant figures and include the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part D
parts.content: Calculate the percentage of the initial energy stored that is delivered to the black box.
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

parts.title: Part E
parts.content: Calculate the time, in milliseconds, it takes to deliver <input id='p15-e-E'/> mJ to the black box.
parts.need: Express your answer with the appropriate units.

problems.title: Problem 16
problems.content: At t=0, a series-connected capacitor and inductor are placed across the terminals of a black box, as shown in (Figure 1). For t>0, it is known that i<sub>o</sub> = 1.5e<sup>-16,000t</sup> - 1.5e<sup>-4000t</sup> A , where t is in seconds.

parts.title: Part A
parts.content: If v<sub>c</sub> (0) = -450 V choose the correct expression for v<sub>o</sub> for t≥0.
